### Chapter 1: The Broken Vow

:::{.cr-section}

:::{#cr-heartbreak}
![](corazon.png)
:::

<span style="display:none;">.</span> [@cr-heartbreak]{scale-by="1.0" opacity="1.0"}

<p>Every divorce is a rupture, a private tragedy scaled across a nation. This map is not just a collection of numbers; it is a geographic representation of pain and fundamental societal shifts in Ecuador.</p>

<p>We begin by acknowledging the emotional weight of the data before diving into the cold statistics.</p>

:::

---

### Chapter 2: The 3.86% Anomaly

:::{.cr-section}

:::{#cr-galapagos}
![](galapagos.png)
:::

<span style="display:none;">.</span> [@cr-galapagos]{scale-by="1.0" opacity="1.0"}

<p>The **Galápagos Islands** stand as the undisputed crisis zone. With a staggering divorce rate of **$3.86\%$**, they represent an extreme statistical outlier.</p>

<p>This anomaly likely stems from the islands' unique pressures: high cost of living, transient populations, and the stress of life in an isolated, protected environment.</p>

:::

---

### Chapter 3: The Continental Divide

:::{.cr-section}

:::{#cr-cañar}
![](cañar.png)
:::

<span style="display:none;">.</span> [@cr-cañar]{scale-by="1.0" opacity="1.0"}

<p>On the mainland, the highest dissolution rates are concentrated in the Sierra. **Cañar ($2.56\%$)** and **Azuay ($2.39\%$)** form a distinct, high-pressure zone.</p>

<p>This suggests that regional economic and social dynamics in the southern highlands are driving instability, demanding targeted social interventions.</p>

:::

---

### Chapter 4: The Quiet Reality

:::{.cr-section}

:::{#cr-esmeraldas}
![](esmeraldas.png)
:::

<span style="display:none;">.</span> [@cr-esmeraldas]{scale-by="1.0" opacity="1.0"}

<p>For every hotspot, there is a counterpoint. Provinces like **Zamora Chinchipe ($0.32\%$)** and **Esmeraldas ($0.53\%$)** show remarkable stability, maintaining the lowest rates in the country.</p>

<p>These regions, often characterized by different economic paces or more resilient traditional structures, offer a vital baseline for understanding marital stability in Ecuador.</p>

:::

---

### Final Chapter: A Call to Policy

:::{.cr-section}

:::{#cr-map}
![](mapa.png)
:::

<span style="display:none;">.</span> [@cr-map]{scale-by="1.0" opacity="1.0"}

<p>The map’s colors tell a clear story: divorce is a deeply geographic phenomenon, driven by specific regional factors, not a uniform national trend.</p>

<p>Policymakers must use this geographic data to tailor support, addressing the specific pressures affecting the most vulnerable regions.</p>

:::
